title: Issue when `module load` command print some extra  messages to stdout
body:
On some of the system when we load a module, there could be extra messages to stdout:
For example, on some systems for commercial compilers with limited licenses I see: 

``` bash
$ module load intel
Warning: The number of floating seats is limited. Do not use make -j as it checks out all the licences preventing other users from working
```

If I specify this module in `compilers.yaml` I get below error:

``` bash
……….
    return_val = command(parser, args)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/cmd/install.py", line 118, in install
    package.do_install(**kwargs)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/package.py", line 1113, in do_install
    spack.build_environment.fork(self, build_process, dirty=dirty)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py", line 532, in fork
    setup_package(pkg, dirty=dirty)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py", line 470, in setup_package
    set_compiler_environment_variables(pkg, spack_env)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py", line 224, in set_compiler_environment_variables
    load_module(mod)
  File "/somepath/spack/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py", line 139, in load_module
    exec(compile(load, '<string>', 'exec'))
  File "<string>", line 24
    Warning: The number of floating seats is limited. Do not use make -j as it checks out all the licences preventing other users from working
           ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
==> Error: Installation process had nonzero exit code : 256
```

I see that these messages might be treated as error or something else but wonder if there is any workaround / better way to handle this.
